answer1.text: For behavioral interviews, try the STAR method — Situation, Task, Action, Result. Think of 4–5 strong stories that demonstrate teamwork, communication, and problem-solving. Also, practice out loud — it helps make your answers sound more natural.

answer2.text: You can keep one master resume and tweak it depending on the role. For consulting, highlight communication, leadership, and problem-solving. For tech, emphasize technical skills and projects. A one-size-fits-all resume usually doesn’t work well.

answer3.text: Ask genuine questions about the speaker’s work — people love talking about their experiences. Follow up with a short LinkedIn message afterward. Even a quick 'thanks for sharing your insights' can go a long way.

answer4.text: Block off time for yourself just like you would for class. I also found it helpful to use separate calendars for work and school so I could visually see my free time. And don’t underestimate the power of sleep.

answer5.text: Absolutely! Keep your profile photo professional, add a summary that reflects your interests, and make sure your experiences have descriptions. Recruiters often filter by keywords — include relevant skills like 'Python', 'UX', or 'data analysis.'

answer6.text: Check Glassdoor reviews and LinkedIn posts from employees. During the interview, ask what a typical week looks like or how they celebrate team wins — those answers can reveal a lot about culture.
